Robert Bronston

  1. Home

  2. Explore Stories

Themes

Athletics
Racism & Resistance
Community

Biography

Robert “Bob” Bronston is an African American alumni who attended Miami University from 1951 to 1955. One of four children, he was born on September 27th, 1933 in Springfield, Ohio to parents Esmond and Naomi Bronston. Robert attended Springfield High School, where he was a member of the varsity basketball team that won the state championship title in 1950. He graduated in 1951.

Robert enrolled at Miami in the fall of 1951 as an education major. A star student athlete, he played for the football team all four years of his college career under Coach Ara Parseghian, and was named “Most Valuable Junior Player” his junior year, and team captain his senior year. He was elected to the Athletic Board of Controls, the advisory council composed of students and faculty, in 1954. Despite his athletic success, Robert’s football career at Miami still saw incidents of racial prejudice and discrimination. One such incident took place during a trip to Wichita his freshman year, when he and ten of his African American teammates were forced to stay in a single hotel room at a separate, lesser quality hotel, while his white coaches and teammates slept comfortably in a nicer hotel across town.

Robert was involved in a number of other student organizations, serving as both president of Tribe Miami— the varsity letterman’s association— and Junior Vice President. He was also a member of the Air Force ROTC on campus. He graduated from Miami in 1955. According to an interview with Bronston in 1996, Parseghian informed Bronston that he wanted him to stay at Miami to work alongside him as an assistant coach following his graduation, the head football coach told him that the university trustees would not allow it because he was Black.

Shortly after graduation, Robert began teaching and coaching football at Springfield South High School— he was the first Black teacher in the district to teach at the secondary level and the first Black football coach both at Springfield and in the now defunct Greater Ohio League athletic conference. In his 1996 interview, Bronston noted how his hiring at Springfield was controversial and prompted five white teachers to threaten to quit the district. He married Beverly Crawford, Miami class of 1956, on June 9th, 1956. The couple had two children together, Rhonda and Tracey. Robert taught at Springfield South High School for eighteen years before being named Dean of Students at Springfield North High School, where he continued to work until he retired in 1984. He holds a master’s degree in education from Wright State University.

Robert was an active member of the Springfield community throughout his life. As a member of the Center Street Y.M.C.A., he served both as chairman of the health and physical committee and as a member of the Board of Directors beginning in 1963. He was appointed to Springfield Metropolitan Housing Authority board of commissioners in 1974, which he served on until 1980. In 1977, Bronston was inducted into the Miami University Athletic Hall of Fame. He was also the recipient of numerous community awards and recognitions, including the Davey Moore Cultural Plaque in 1987 and Springfield City School District “Alumni of Distinction Award” in 2017

Credits

Written by Laurel Myers, (4, History & American Studies, 2023)
